January

1 January

At the Battle of Lech in Austria, the army of the Holy Roman Empire, led by King Wenceslaus IV, defeats the invading forces of King Ottokar III of Bohemia and his allies, thus ending the Bohemian-Austrian War and cementing the Kingdom of Bohemia to the Holy Roman Empire, with its capital in Prague.|0
The governor of Montana is the head of government of Montana and the commander-in-chief of the state's military forces. The governor has a duty to enforce state laws
column2: the power to either approve or veto bills passed by the Montana State Legislature
column3: to convene the legislature at any time
column4: and to grant pardons and reprieves.The current Montana Constitution
column5: ratified in 1972
column6: calls for a 4-year term for the governor
column7: commencing on the first Monday in January following an election. The governor is term-limited to 8 years in any 16-year period. The constitution provides for the election of a lieutenant governor for the same term as the governor.|1

column1: Observations show that the expansion of the universe is accelerating
column2: such that the velocity at which a distant galaxy recedes from the observer is continuously increasing with time.The accelerated expansion was discovered during 1998
column3: by two independent projects
column4: the Supernova Cosmology Project and the High-Z Supernova Search Team
column5: which both used distant type Ia supernovae to measure the acceleration. The idea was that as type Ia supernovae have almost the same intrinsic brightness (a standard candle)
column6: and since objects that are further away appear dimmer
column7: we can use the observed brightness of these supernovae to measure the distance to them.|1

column1: In cosmology
column2: the cosmological constant (usually denoted by the Greek capital letter lambda: Λ)
column3: alternatively called Einstein's cosmological constant
column4: is the constant coefficient of a term Albert Einstein temporarily added to his field equations of general relativity. He later removed it. Much later it was revived and reinterpreted as the energy density of space
column5: or vacuum energy
column6: that arises in quantum mechanics. It is closely associated with the concept of dark energy.Einstein originally introduced the constant in 1917 to counterbalance the effect of gravity and achieve a static universe
column7: a notion which was the accepted view at the time.|1

column1: Algebraic topology is a branch of mathematics that uses tools from abstract algebra to study topological spaces . The basic notion of a topological space is a set that has a family of subsets called open sets, such that every element of a set has a unique neighborhood of a certain type. Two spaces that are "topologically equivalent" or "homeomorphic" are spaces that can be continuously deformed from one to the other using these open sets. In the category of topological spaces and continuous mappings, two spaces are equivalent if and only if they have the same homotopy type.|0

Figure skating jumps are an element of three competitive figure skating disciplines—men's singles, ladies' singles, and pair skating but not ice dancing. Jumping in figure skating is "relatively recent". They were originally individual compulsory figures, and sometimes special figures; many jumps were named after the skaters who invented them or from the figures from which they were developed. It was not until the early part of the 20th century, well after the establishment of organized skating competitions, when jumps with the potential of being completed with multiple revolutions were invented and when jumps were formally categorized.|1

column1: Year 1392 (MCCCXCII) was a leap year starting on Monday (link will display full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  January–December  June 13 – An assassination attempt by Pierre de Craon against Olivier de Clisson, Constable of France, fails. August 5 General Yi Seong-gye crowns himself Taejo of Joseon, ending the Goryeo Dynasty in the Korean Peninsula, and establishing the Joseon Dynasty, which will last for more than 500 years. Charles VI of France (later known as "Charles the Mad") suffers a serious bout of psychosis, which will continue throughout his life.|1

The Mattachine Society , founded in 1950 , was an early national gay rights organization in the United States , and is now defunct. The Mattachine Society was formed out of the frustration of the lack of progress towards gay rights, and was founded by Allan Ginsberg. The Mattachine Society published the newspaper, "Mattachine News", and an underground newspaper, "Rat". In the beginning of Mattachine Society, it focused on legal reform, but it later focused on social reform. This organization worked to increase the status of homosexuals in American society, and they worked towards abolishing anti-gay laws.|0

Ice hockey at the 2002 Winter Olympics was held at the E Center in West Valley City and Peaks Ice Center in Frisco. This was the second time that the Winter Olympic ice hockey tournaments were held in the United States, the first being held at the Lake Placid 1980 Winter Olympic Games in Lake Placid. The 2002 Winter Olympic games were the first games held in the American state of Utah since 1968. Qualification

North America
North America consisted of the United States, Canada (excluding Quebec and Ontario) and Mexico. Each country was limited to 2 entries per gender in the tournaments.|0

column1: Roger Williams (21 December 1603between 27 January and 15 March 1683) was a Puritan minister, theologian, and author who founded Providence Plantations, which became the Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations and later the U.S. State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations, now the State of Rhode Island. He was a staunch advocate for religious freedom, separation of church and state, and fair dealings with Native Americans.Williams was expelled by the Puritan leaders from the Massachusetts Bay Colony and established Providence Plantations in 1636 as a refuge offering what he termed "liberty of conscience."|1

column1: The Khlysts or Khlysty (,  "whips") were an underground Spiritual Christian sect, which split from the Russian Orthodox Church and existed from the 1600s until the late 20th century.NameThe members of the sect referred to themselves by various names, including "God's People" (liudi bozh'i), "followers of Christ's faith" (Khristovovery), or simply "Christs" (Khristy). The appellation "Khlysty" is a derogatory term applied by critics of the sect. The origin of the term is disputed.|1

Arthur Andersen LLP was an American holding company based in Chicago. Formerly one of the "Big Five" accounting firms (along with PricewaterhouseCoopers, Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, Ernst & Young, and KPMG), the company had provided auditing, tax and consulting services to large corporations. By 2001, it had become one of the world's largest multinational corporations.In 2002, the firm voluntarily surrendered its licenses to practice as Certified Public Accountants in the United States after it was found guilty of crimes in the firm's auditing of Enron, an energy corporation based in Texas, which had filed for bankruptcy in 2001.|1

column1: Symbiosis (from Greek , , "living together", from , , "together", and , bíōsis, "living") is any type of a close and long-term biological interaction between two different biological organisms, be it mutualistic, commensalistic, or parasitic. The organisms, each termed a symbiont, must be of different species. In 1879, Heinrich Anton de Bary defined it as "the living together of unlike organisms". The term was subject to a century-long debate about whether it should specifically denote mutualism, as in lichens.|1

Year 1295 ( MCCXCV ) was a common year starting on Saturday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. In England it was preceded in the year 1295 relative to the Gregorian/Modern calendar by the Julian year 1294 and is reckoned as the 19th year of the 130th indiction (130th year of the post-Conquest indiction cycle). It corresponds with the Kalenderjahr 1294 in the German Julian calendar. The leap year 1594 is not the leap year 1595 according to Julian/Gregorian calculation. ( Julian/Gregorian leap year definition ) In England it is counted as the leap year 1595.|0

column1: A sifaka   is a lemur of the genus Propithecus from the family Indriidae within the order Primates. The name of their family is an onomatopoeia of their characteristic "shi-fak" alarm call. Like all lemurs, they are found only on the island of Madagascar. All species of sifakas are threatened, ranging from endangered to critically endangered.Anatomy and physiology Sifakas are medium-sized indrids with a head and body length of  and a weight of . Their tail is just as long as their body, which differentiates them from the Indri. Their fur is long and silky, with coloration varying by species from yellowish-white to blackish-brown.|1

column1: In mathematics, an -sphere or a hypersphere is a topological space that is homeomorphic to a standard -sphere, which is the set of points in -dimensional Euclidean space that are situated at a constant distance  from a fixed point, called the center. It is the generalization of an ordinary sphere in the ordinary three-dimensional space. The "radius" of a sphere is the constant distance of its points to the center. When the sphere has unit radius, it is usual to call it the unit -sphere or simply the -sphere for brevity.|1

column1: In software quality assurance

column5: such as scalability
column6: reliability and resource usage.Performance testing
column7: a subset of performance engineering
column8: is a computer science practice which strives to build performance standards into the implementation

Frederick II of Brandenburg ( 19 November 1413 – 10 February 1471 ) , nicknamed `` the Iron '' ( Eisenhart ) , was King of Bohemia ( 1457 – 1471) and King of Jerusalem ( 1461–71), and a crusader king (1446–56). In 1449, Frederick was crowned King of Denmark in opposition to his nephew, King Christian I. He was deposed in 1464, although he continued as a de facto king of Denmark until 1466. [1][2]

Contents

Frederick II was the first child of Duke John II of Saxe-Lauenburg and Margareta, a daughter of Count Otto III von Lusatia.|0

column1: Nvidia Corporation  is an American multinational technology company incorporated in Delaware and based in Santa Clara, California. It is a fabless company which designs graphics processing units (GPUs) for the gaming and professional markets, as well as system on a chip units (SoCs) for the mobile computing and automotive market. column1:
Spins are an element in figure skating in which the skater rotates , centered on a single point on the ice surface , in one direction and then in the other in a clockwise or counterclockwise fashion. Spin is an important element of technical skating, but is also important as a component of performance and aesthetics in Figure skating. The technique of spinning in Figure skating consists of a sequence of movements of the body and arms of the skaters that are aimed at producing a spinning movement. Spinning is typically done in one of two basic positions:

with the arms extended out to the side

with the arms bent forward.|0

column2: or chatroom (and sometimes group chat; abbreviated as GC)
column3: is primarily used to describe any form of synchronous conferencing
column4: occasionally even asynchronous conferencing. The term can thus mean any technology ranging from real-time online chat and online interaction with strangers (e.g.
column5: online forums) to fully immersive graphical social environments.The primary use of a chat room is to share information via text with a group of other users. Generally speaking
column6: the ability to converse with multiple people in the same conversation differentiates chat rooms from instant messaging programs
column7: which are more typically designed for one-to-one communication.|1

column1: `` Coven '' usually refers to a group or gathering of witches . The word `` coven '' ( from the Celtic word * kove ) usually refers to an organized group of witches who practice or perform certain coven ceremonies. The word has also been applied to groups of occultists practicing magic and other forms of esoteric knowledge in secrecy
column2: and which use magical rites and traditions to achieve their goals. Often a coven may be part of another larger coven which is the group in charge of that particular coven and its practices
column3: but a group of magical covens may exist independently of larger groups of related covens.|0

column1: GNU Privacy Guard (GnuPG or GPG) is a free-software replacement for Symantec's PGP cryptographic software suite. The software is compliant with RFC 4880
column2: the IETF standards-track specification of OpenPGP. Modern versions of PGP are interoperable with GnuPG and other OpenPGP-compliant systems.GnuPG is part of the GNU Project and received major funding from the German government in 1999.Overview GnuPG is a hybrid-encryption software program because it uses a combination of conventional symmetric-key cryptography for speed
column3: and public-key cryptography for ease of secure key exchange
column4: typically by using the recipient's public key to encrypt a session key which is used only once.|1

column1: Botulinum toxin ( BoNT ) is a neurotoxic protein produced by the bacterium Clostridium botulinum and related species . It can be used as an ingredient to treat many health conditions
column2: such as muscle pain or spasms

column4: and pain associated with fibromyalgia. It also reduces the symptoms of Parkinson's disease

column1: Uracil  (symbol U or Ura) is one of the four nucleobases in the nucleic acid RNA that are represented by the letters A, G, C and U. The others are adenine (A), cytosine (C), and guanine (G). In RNA, uracil binds to adenine via two hydrogen bonds. In DNA, the uracil nucleobase is replaced by thymine. Uracil is a demethylated form of thymine.Uracil is a common and naturally occurring pyrimidine derivative. The name "uracil" was coined in 1885 by the German chemist Robert Behrend, who was attempting to synthesize derivatives of uric acid.|1

A conjugate acid
column2: within the Brønsted–Lowry acid–base theory
column3: is a chemical compound formed when an acid donates a hydrogen cation
column4: or proton (usually H+) to a weakly basic compound that contains a hydroxide group. For example
column5: HCl is a conjugate acid. Because of conjugation
column6: hydrogen ions can be removed from the acid by forming a conjugate acid
column7: and replaced by an electronegative counter-ion. In particular
column8: the conjugate anions of the conjugate bases of strong acids are the conjugate bases of weak acids
column9: because strong acids are relatively unreactive.|0

column1: The Æsir (Old Norse: ) are the gods of the principal pantheon in Norse religion. They include Odin, Frigg, Höðr, Thor, and Baldr. The second Norse pantheon is the Vanir. In Norse mythology, the two pantheons wage war against each other, resulting in a unified pantheon. Unlike the Old English word god (and the Old Norse word ), Æsir was never converted over to Christian use.EtymologyÆsir is the plural of áss, ǫ́ss "god". In genitival compounds, it takes the form , e.g.|1

Banksia is a genus of around 170 species in the plant family Proteaceae. These Australian wildflowers and popular garden plants are easily recognised by their characteristic flower spikes and fruiting "cones" and heads. Banksias range in size from prostrate woody shrubs to trees up to 30 metres (100 ft) tall. They are found in a wide variety of landscapes: sclerophyll forest, (occasionally) rainforest, shrubland, and some more arid landscapes, though not in Australia's deserts.Heavy producers of nectar, banksias are a vital part of the food chain in the Australian bush.|1
Mariner 10 was an American robotic space probe launched by NASA on 3 November 1973
column2: to fly by the planets Mercury and Venus. It was the first spacecraft to perform flybys of multiple planets.Mariner 10 was launched approximately two years after Mariner 9 and was the last spacecraft in the Mariner program. (Mariner 11 and Mariner 12 were allocated to the Voyager program and redesignated Voyager 1 and Voyager 2. )The mission objectives were to measure Mercury's environment
column3: atmosphere
column4: surface
column5: and body characteristics and to make similar investigations of Venus.|1

Year 1404 ( MCDIV ) was a leap year starting on Tuesday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar and a leap year of the Proleptic Gregorian calendar. Events [ edit ]

July 10, 1404 — King Philip II of France signed a treaty of friendship and mutual defense with Pope Eugene IV. He also agreed, on behalf of his father, to support the pope's cause against King Charles VII of France. column1: Gravity , or gravitation , is a natural phenomenon by which all things with mass or energy , including planets and stars , remain in orbit around a planet or star. The natural attraction of mass is so strong that it creates a force on other bodies that counteracts the force of gravity and brings those bodies back towards the planet or star . This is also termed as "inertia", as the force that causes an object to stay where it is and not be in motion. This force is measured in the unit of Newtons .|0

column1: La Ruffiana is an older female character of the Commedia dell'Arte with a shady past or who used to be a prostitute. She is used most often in relationship to the vecchi of which group she is a nominal member. Ruffiana is most often romantically involved with Pantalone, though his love may easily be unrequited if it suits the plot. She is generally described as being talkative/gossipy, sneaky, and mischievous, but deep down is actually kind. She has been described as an "outsider" that always mixes things up and causes trouble for the rest of the characters.|1

Adnams is a regional brewery founded in 1872 in Southwold , Suffolk , England , by George and Ernest Adnams , originally as Adnams Breweries Ltd. The two brothers started brewing at Southwold brewery in 1865 , and their first ale, "The Southwold", was brewed in 1872 . George Adnams died in 1896 , with Ernest running the business for a number of years until his son, Ernest Ernest Adnams, became head brewer in 1901 . Ernest's son, Arthur , took over the reins of the brewery in 1947 . Adnams beers are among the most popular in England and some of the best known beers in the world.|0
A Tesla coil is an electrical resonant transformer circuit designed by inventor Nikola Tesla in 1891 . It is used to create high voltage

column4: AC Tesla coils
column5: and Tesla coils powered by high power direct current or DC. Tesla coils use alternating current power to create their high voltage and current. The power supply can consist of a generator
column6: battery
column7: rectifier
column8: inverter
column9: capacitor
column10: and transformer.|0

column1: Alpine skiing, or downhill skiing, is the pastime of sliding down snow-covered slopes on skis with fixed-heel bindings, unlike other types of skiing (cross-country, Telemark, or ski jumping), which use skis with free-heel bindings. Whether for recreation or for sport, it is typically practiced at ski resorts, which provide such services as ski lifts, artificial snow making, snow grooming, restaurants, and ski patrol. "Off-piste" skiers—those skiing outside ski area boundaries—may employ snowmobiles, helicopters or snowcats to deliver them to the top of a slope.|1

The 7th millennium BC spanned the years 7000 BC to 6001 BC ( c. 9 ka to c. 8 ka). The period is generally defined as being from the time of the First Dynasty (c. 2500 BC to c. 2500 BC) in Egypt to the Second Dynasty in the Late Bronze Age of Syria-Palestine. It was the time when most of the cities and states of the ancient Near East came under control of Egypt. During the period
column2: Egypt became dominant over Mesopotamia and the Aegean world
column3: though it was not always in complete control.|0

column1: Dari ( , , ) , or Dari Persian , is a political term used for the various dialects of Persian. The term "Dari Persian" is used to refer to dialects used in Iran and Afghanistan. Observations show that the expansion of the universe is accelerating
column2: such that the velocity at which a distant galaxy is moving increases as the distance to it decreases. In other words
column3: there is no recession
column4: and this acceleration means that the distance to galaxies is increasing. This is in contradiction with the idea of a finite universe
column5: and so the cause of cosmic acceleration has remained elusive. A simple explanation for this is in Einstein’s cosmological constant
column6: but this has been ruled out by astronomical observations . A new approach to the problem is offered by an idea of quantum entanglement .|0

column1: The Cathedral of St. John the Divine ( sometimes referred to as St. John 's and also nicknamed St. John the Wonder Worker or Saint John the Wonder-working Christ) is an American Episcopal church on Morningside Heights in the Manhattan borough of New York City

column3: and the cathedral is the largest building in the Episcopal Diocese of New York. The cathedral is often called the 'mother church' of the Episcopal Church.|0

column1: Nature versus nurture is a long-standing debate in biology about the balance between two competing factors which determine fate : nature and nurture. Nature deals with the biological inheritance of an organism
column2: which is the product of the genes within the germ cells of the parents
column3: while Nurture is the environmental experience that shapes the individual throughout life. Many researchers agree that nature plays a greater role in shaping an individual and that nurture plays a less important role. The debate is complicated by the idea that both nature and nurture have significant effects on each other: an individual's environment is influenced by his biology.|0

column1: Divorce ( also known as dissolution of marriage ) is the process of terminating a marriage or marital union . Divorce in the United States differs from legal separation in that it requires court approval and does not automatically terminate the marriage . Although divorce does not necessarily require an actual separation
column2: it is frequently followed by a legal separation
column3: which is a unilateral withdrawal of one party from a marriage or legal partnership . The divorce process in many countries is a series of legal proceedings
column4: which can last years . The divorce process typically involves legal representation
column5: financial settlements
column6: and custody issues .|0

column1: In software quality assurance
column2: performance testing is in general a testing practice performed to determine how a system performs under given conditions. This testing is usually focused on measuring throughput
column3: resource usage
column4: memory utilization etc. While performance is typically measured as a performance test
column5: some performance testing methods such as application load balancing are also considered software quality assurance methodologies
column6: as they aim to improve software quality indirectly . In this article we'll discuss the different types of performance tests. The most widely known and recognized performance test type is benchmarking.|0

column1: In physics, quintessence is a hypothetical form of dark energy, more precisely a scalar field, postulated  as an explanation of the observation  of an accelerating rate of expansion of the universe. The first example of this scenario was proposed by Ratra and Peebles (1988). The concept was expanded to more general types of time-varying dark energy and the term "quintessence" was first introduced in a 1998 paper by Robert R. Caldwell, Rahul Dave and Paul Steinhardt. It has been proposed by some physicists to be a fifth fundamental force.|1

Greyhound racing is an organized , competitive sport in which greyhounds are raced around a track . There are two classes of greyhound races: sprint or lure . In lure racing, the goal is not to reach a certain speed but to win by running as fast as possible around a course . In sprint racing , the goal is to run the fastest possible distance , usually 300 yards . Contents

Sprints are run at different distances , such as 440 , 480 , 560 and 600 yards. Some tracks have separate races to compete in.|0

Wenceslaus IV ( also Wenceslas ; ; , nicknamed `` the Idle '' ; 26 February 136116 August 1419 ) was king of Germany and Bohemia, Holy Roman Emperor and King of Rome, from 1378 to 1419. column1: Slapstick is a style of humor involving exaggerated physical activity that exceeds the boundaries of normal physical comedy . Slapstick is often performed by actors and comedians in slapstick comedies . The term originated in early 19th century Britain to describe comic actors performing exaggerated movements and facial expressions. It was also applied to the exaggerated actions of the puppets in puppet theatre . The word is derived from the French word "slappe", "slap" or the Italian "slap" meaning to hit. The English meaning derives from the German "Schlappen", "slap on the shoulder".|0

column8: F and G). New types are occasionally found. Types A and B are capable of causing disease in humans

Optical rotation
column2: also known as polarization rotation or circular birefringence
column3: is the rotation of the orientation of the plane of polarization about the optical axis of linearly polarized light as it travels through certain materials. Circular birefringence and circular dichroism are the manifestations of optical activity. Optical activity occurs only in chiral materials
column4: those lacking microscopic mirror symmetry. Unlike other sources of birefringence which alter a beam's state of polarization
column5: optical activity can be observed in fluids. This can include gases or solutions of chiral molecules such as sugars
column6: molecules with helical secondary structure such as some proteins
column7: and also chiral liquid crystals.|1

column1: Bdellovibrio is a genus of Gram-negative , obligate aerobic bacterium . One of the more notable characteristics of this genus is the ability to reproduce through a process termed "binary fission". Bdellovibrio reproduce using a "nucleoid"-like particle called the piliation that moves towards the cell center. In Bdellovibrio this process is used to separate one bacterial cell into two daughter cells. During this process the B. bacteriovorus and Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus HD100 ( BDBV HD100)  are divided in half and the resulting organisms are called the "nucleoids". These nucleoids can then be used to infect other bacteria .|0

Lazzi ( ; from the Italian lazzo , a joke or witticism ) are stock comedic routines that are associated with many kinds of entertainers. Lazzi have been widely copied in Italian literature, especially the satirical prose of Carlo Goldoni, and in Italian theatre from the late eighteenth century. The word lazzo was first recorded in English by Francis Grose as "la-sco" in 1785, and in a 1789 edition of the English Dialect Dictionary it is defined as a joke, "jest, merry tale, pleasantry, tale, jest".|0

column1: The Cross of Gold speech was delivered by William Jennings Bryan, a former United States Representative from Nebraska, at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago on July 9, 1896. In the address, Bryan supported bimetallism or "free silver", which he believed would bring the nation prosperity. He decried the gold standard, concluding the speech, "you shall not crucify mankind upon a cross of gold". Bryan's address helped catapult him to the Democratic Party's presidential nomination; it is considered one of the greatest political speeches in American history.For twenty years, Americans had been bitterly divided over the nation's monetary standard.|1

Algebraic topology is a branch of mathematics that uses tools from abstract algebra to study topological spaces. The basic goal is to find algebraic invariants that classify topological spaces up to homeomorphism

column3: using topology to solve algebraic problems is sometimes also possible. Algebraic topology
column4: for example
column5: allows for a convenient proof that any subgroup of a free group is again a free group.Main branches of algebraic topologyBelow are some of the main areas studied in algebraic topology:Homotopy groupsIn mathematics
column6: homotopy groups are used in algebraic topology to classify topological spaces.|1

column1: Casimir IV (in full Casimir IV Andrew Jagiellon;  ; Lithuanian: ; 30 November 1427 – 7 June 1492) was Grand Duke of Lithuania from 1440 and King of Poland from 1447, until his death. He was one of the most active Polish-Lithuanian rulers, under whom Poland, by defeating the Teutonic Knights in the Thirteen Years' War recovered Pomerania, and the Jagiellonian dynasty became one of the leading royal houses in Europe.The great triumph of his reign was bringing Prussia under Polish rule. The rule of Casimir corresponded to the age of "new monarchies" in western Europe.|1

"Coven"  usually refers to a group or gathering of witches. The word "coven" (from Anglo-Norman covent, cuvent, from Old French covent, from Latin conventum = convention) remained largely unused in English until 1921 when Margaret Murray promoted the idea that all witches across Europe met in groups of thirteen which they called "covens".NeopaganismIn Wicca and other similar forms of neopagan witchcraft, such as Stregheria and Feri, a coven is a gathering or community of witches, like an affinity group, engagement group, or small covenant group.|1

The Asian Games , also known as Asiad , is a continental multi-sport event held every four years among athletes from Asia . History 
The first Asiad, in Jakarta in 1962, was held as a "test" of the Olympic movement to gauge whether Asia was ready to play a bigger part in the Olympic movement. It proved a huge success, with several of the first Olympians in their sport participating. The next two Asiad were in 1963 and 1965, the only other two Olympic Games staged in Asia, in Tokyo and Tel Aviv.|0

He won the Dutch National Sprint Championships in 1991 and 1995. At the 1994 World Sprint Championships he finished third.|0

column1: Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne tropical disease caused by the dengue virus. Symptoms typically begin three to fourteen days after infection. These may include a high fever
column2: headache
column3: vomiting
column4: muscle and joint pains
column5: and a characteristic skin rash. Recovery generally takes two to seven days. In a small proportion of cases
column6: the disease develops into a more severe dengue hemorrhagic fever
column7: resulting in bleeding
column8: low levels of blood platelets and blood plasma leakage
column9: or into dengue shock syndrome
column10: where dangerously low blood pressure occurs.Dengue is spread by several species of female mosquitoes of the Aedes genus

column1: Andrew Stuart "Andy" Fastow (born December 22, 1961) is a convicted felon and former financier who was the chief financial officer of Enron Corporation, an energy trading company based in Houston, Texas, until he was fired shortly before the company declared bankruptcy. The Zwinger is a palatial complex with gardens in Dresden , Germany . Designed by architect Matthäus Daniel Pöppelmann , it was constructed between 1610 and 1618 by King Augustus as a gift to his sister-in-law Sophia Eleonore of the Palatinate . The complex is now open to the public. It is the first building that is listed in the UNESCO Memory of the World register . Contents show]

Architecture

The Zwinger's plan is unique among Saxon buildings, in that the main courtyard, rather than being in the front of the building like in the case of most houses of the time, is in the back.|0

Acetic acid bacteria (AAB) are a group of Gram-negative bacteria which oxidize sugars or ethanol and produce acetic acid during fermentation. The acetic acid bacteria consist of 10 genera in the family Acetobacteraceae. Several species of acetic acid bacteria are used in industry for production of certain foods and chemicals.DescriptionAll acetic acid bacteria are rod-shaped and obligate aerobes. Acetic acid bacteria are airborne and are ubiquitous in nature. They are actively present in environments where ethanol is being formed as a product of the fermentation of sugars. They can be isolated from the nectar of flowers and from damaged fruit.|1

column1: A conjugate acid

column3: is a  chemical compound formed when an acid donates a proton (H+) to a base—in other words

column8: as in the reverse reaction it is able to gain a hydrogen ion.|1

column1: Cooking bananas are banana cultivars in the genus Musa whose fruits are generally used in cooking. They may be eaten ripe or unripe and are generally starchy. Many cooking bananas are referred to as plantains (/ˈplæntɪn/ US: /plænˈteɪn/,UK: /ˈplɑːntɪn/) or green bananas. In botanical usage, the term "plantain" is used only for true plantains, while other starchy cultivars used for cooking are called "cooking bananas". True plantains are cultivars belonging to the AAB Group, while cooking bananas are any cultivars belonging to AAB, AAA, ABB, or BBB groups.|1

column1: Acetic acid bacteria ( AAB ) are a group of Gram-negative bacteria which oxidize sugars or ethanol and produce acetic acid as their major end-product. They also play an important role in bioleaching and the bioconversion of organic matter to biofuels. Due to their important roles in biotechnology and bioenergy
column2: AABs have been extensively studied. Recent work has led to the discovery of a new and more diverse group of acetic acid bacteria and has provided insight into the evolution of AABs and their role in biotechnology. This review discusses these recent discoveries as well as the implications they have for the study and application of AABs and their future research direction.|0

column1: Michelangelo Antonioni  (, ; 29 September 1912 – 30 July 2007) was an Italian film director, screenwriter, editor, and painter. He is best known for his "trilogy on modernity and its discontents"—L'Avventura (1960), La Notte (1961), and L'Eclisse (1962)—as well as the English-language films Blowup (1966) and The Passenger (1975). column1: Botulism is a rare and potentially fatal illness caused by a toxin produced by the bacterium Clostridium botulinum . The first symptoms of botulism are weakness
column2: slurred speech and facial paralysis
column3: followed by difficulty breathing. The paralysis may progress to paralysis of the muscles of the arms and legs and death. Prompt treatment with an antitoxin can be effective for most adults and children. For those who are affected
column4: recovery usually takes several weeks or months. Botulinum toxin can be injected into muscles and injected subcutaneously as a preventive measure. Injecting into muscles can be painful.|0

An engagement ring is a ring indicating that the person wearing it is engaged to be married , especially in the western world . While there are several other jewelry items that can be given to a woman who is dating , the engagement ring remains as the most popular and traditional wedding band . History of Engagement Rings

The origin of the engagement ring date back to ancient times.|0

column1: A compass is a device that shows the cardinal directions used for navigation and geographic orientation. It commonly consists of a magnetized needle or other element

column4: including gyroscopes
column5: magnetometers
column6: and GPS receivers.Compasses often show angles in degrees: north corresponds to 0°
column7: and the angles increase clockwise
column8: so east is 90°
column9: south is 180°
column10: and west is 270°. These numbers allow the compass to show azimuths or bearings which are commonly stated in degrees.|1

Abolitionism , or the abolitionist movement , was the movement to end slavery . In Western Europe and the Americas, the movement began as a political movement during the 18th century, and led to the abolition of slavery in most of the Americas by the early 19th century. Abolitionists also campaigned against the institution of servitude and for the civil rights of the enslaved, and worked for social justice and racial equality. Abolition of slavery has been called a "moral crusade", a "social crusade" and an "anti-colonial rebellion". Abolitionism is the earliest and most successful antislavery movement to achieve worldwide political and social influence.|0

Jon Howard Appleton ( January 4 , 1939 – January 30 , 2022 ) was an American composer , an educator , and a writer of children's literature . He composed music for more than one hundred motion pictures , television shows , and theater plays . Howard was nominated for the Academy Award in Music for co-writing the title song from Annie Get Your Gun (1950), and was nominated for the Golden Globe for the title song from Annie (1977). Biography and Early Life

Howard Appleton was born on 4 January 1939 in San Francisco, California and was raised in Palo Alto and Menlo Park, California .|0

The picometre ( international spelling as used by the International Bureau of Weights and Measures ; SI symbol : pm ) is a metric prefix for units of volume (e.g., litre, cubic metre, cubic foot). 1. Picometre

2. Picometre is not to be confused with micrometre, a unit of measurement in which the distance is much smaller. 2.|0

Nature versus nurture is a long-standing debate in biology about the balance between two competing factors which determine fate: environment (nurture) and genetics (nature). The alliterative expression "nature and nurture" in English has been in use since at least the Elizabethan period and goes back to medieval French.The complementary combination of the two concepts is an ancient concept . Nature is what people think of as pre-wiring and is influenced by genetic inheritance and other biological factors. Nurture is generally taken as the influence of external factors after conception e.g.|1

arXiv (pronounced "archive"—the X represents the Greek letter chi [χ]) is an open-access repository of electronic preprints and postprints (known as e-prints) approved for posting after moderation, but not peer review. It consists of scientific papers in the fields of mathematics, physics, astronomy, electrical engineering, computer science, quantitative biology, statistics, mathematical finance and economics, which can be accessed online. In many fields of mathematics and physics, almost all scientific papers are self-archived on the arXiv repository before publication in a peer-reviewed journal.|1

Bobsleigh or bobsled is a team winter sport that involves making timed runs down narrow , twisting , banked , and icy slopes on sleds (or sometimes a pair of snowmobiles). The sport originated in Canada and has grown to the point that many countries around the world participate in some form of competition. The International Olympic Committee recognizes bobsledding as an "extreme" winter sport. Contents show]

History Edit

Before bobsleigh evolved into the sport we now know, people used to slide down the mountain on sledges. The best known examples of this activity were the Roman gladiators.|0

As  he belonged to the House of Luxembourg, he was also Duke of Luxembourg from 1383 to 1388.BiographyWenceslaus was born in the Imperial city of Nuremberg, the son of Emperor Charles IV by his third wife Anna von Schweidnitz, a scion of the Silesian Piasts, and baptized at St. Sebaldus Church.|1

column1: Moore's law is the observation that the number of transistors in a dense integrated circuit (IC) doubles about every two years. Moore's law is an observation and projection of a historical trend. Rather than a law of physics
column2: it is an empirical relationship linked to gains from experience in production.The observation is named after Gordon Moore
column3: the co-founder of Fairchild Semiconductor and Intel (and former CEO of the latter)
column4: who in 1965 posited a doubling every year in the number of components per integrated circuit
column5: and projected this rate of growth would continue for at least another decade.|1

column1: Dari (, , ), or Dari Persian , is a political term used for the various dialects of the Persian language spoken in Afghanistan. Dari is the term officially recognised and promoted since 1964 by the Afghan government for the Persian language, hence it is known as Afghan Persian or Eastern Persian in many Western sources. As Professor Nile Green remarks "the impulses behind renaming of Afghan Persian as Dari were more nationalistic than linguistic" in order to create an Afghan state narrative. Persian in Afghanistan is generally called Fārsi (فارسی) by Persian-speakers and Pārsi (پارسی) by ethnic Pashtuns.|1

column1: Moore 's law is the observation that the number of transistors in a dense integrated circuit ( IC ) doubles approximately every two years
column2: which is predicted to continue for another 20 years. Moore ' s law predicts a doubling of the size of an IC about every two years over the next two decades. It is based on two facts. The number of transistors on a typical IC is already doubling approximately every two years

column1: In mathematics , two sets are said to be disjoint sets if they have no element in common . Equivalently , a set is disjoint from another set if it has no element in common with that set . In set theory , the term "disjoint set" is sometimes reserved for a set that is contained in no larger set . As an example , consider the sets A = {1, 2, 3} and B = {4 , 5, 6} , the union of which is equal to the set of all natural numbers .|0

column1: A trisomy is a type of polysomy in which there are three instances of a particular chromosome

column1: Lead azide   is an inorganic compound. More so than other azides
column2: is explosive. It is used in detonators to initiate secondary explosives. In a commercially usable form
column3: it is a white to buff powder.Preparation and handlingLead azide is prepared by the reaction of sodium azide and lead(II) nitrate in aqueous solution. column4: it is normally shipped in a dextrinated solution that lowers its sensitivity.Production historyLead azide in its pure form was first prepared by Theodor Curtius in 1891.|1

column1: Prince Igor  is an opera in four acts with a prologue, written and composed by Alexander Borodin. The composer adapted the libretto from the Ancient Russian epic The Lay of Igor's Host, which recounts the campaign of Rus' prince Igor Svyatoslavich against the invading Cuman ("Polovtsian") tribes in 1185. He also incorporated material drawn from two medieval Kievan chronicles. The opera was left unfinished upon the composer's death in 1887 and was edited and completed by Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov and Alexander Glazunov. It was first performed in St. Petersburg, Russia, in 1890.|1

John the Apostle ( ; ) or Saint John the Beloved was one of the Twelve Apostles of Jesus according to Christian tradition, and was known by this name at the time of his execution in Ephesus. According to the Gospels, he is the author of the Gospel of John. [1]

There are different traditions that describe John as a son of Zebedee, brother to James and James's son[2] (James is sometimes identified as the elder brother, but it is uncertain) or as the son of the Baptist's brother Simon,[2] though these are often conflated into one.|0

A horoscope (or other commonly used names for the horoscope in English include natal chart, astrological chart, astro-chart, celestial map, sky-map, star-chart, cosmogram, vitasphere, radical chart, radix, chart wheel or simply chart) is an astrological chart or diagram representing the positions of the Sun, Moon, planets, astrological aspects and sensitive angles at the time of an event, such as the moment of a person's birth. The word horoscope is derived from the Greek words ōra and scopos meaning "time" and "observer" (horoskopos, pl.|1

A shank is a type of knot that is used to shorten a rope or take up slack , such as in rappelling. The shank is often used as an emergency climbing device to prevent a person from falling in the event a fall arrest line breaks and they fall. Overview 
Shanks are used to shorten the length of a rope so that a climber's fall does not exceed a certain length. For example, a climber's fall from a height of 30 feet (9.1 m) is considered a critical fall and likely to cause injury.|0

Mercia ( , ; ) was one of the kingdoms of the Anglo-Saxon Heptarchy . The name is a Latinisation of a name meaning "land of the Mercians". It was founded in the 5th or 6th century as a client kingdom of the Anglo-Saxons (as the West Saxons) but after the end of the Saxon Wars (the Battle of Edington in 941) it was given the status of an independent kingdom. It is now a part of the counties of the East Riding of Yorkshire and the ceremonial county of West Yorkshire, England.|0

A business plan is a formal written document containing the goals of a business , the methods for attaining those goals , a description of the company's products and services . Contents

The basic elements of a viable business plan include:

Objectives

Market analysis

Organizational structure

Products or services

Management team and financials

Competition

Financial strategy

A business plan can serve as an invaluable tool for the entrepreneur seeking venture financing, investors, lenders and the public. In essence, a business plan describes the product or service the entrepreneur plans to offer to the public. It is not a legal document .|0

column3: ancient and modern

Hawaii Five-O is an American police procedural drama series produced by CBS Productions and created by Leonard Freeman. Set in Hawaii, the show originally aired for 12 seasons from 1968 to 1980, and continues in reruns. At the airing of its last episode, it was the longest-running police drama in American television history and the last fictional primetime show that debuted in the 1960s to leave the air.The show starred Jack Lord as Detective Captain Stephen "Steve" McGarrett, the head of a special state police task force in Hawaii which was based on an actual unit that existed under martial law after  World War II.|1

column2: instead of the normal two. A trisomy is a type of aneuploidy (an abnormal number of chromosomes).Description and causesMost organisms that reproduce sexually have pairs of chromosomes in each cell

Pope Innocent IV died in 1280, and was replaced by Clement IV on May 3 of that year. Pope Urban IV, who took the name Clement V after his election, died in 1314 and was replaced by Clement V on October 16, 1314 .|0
In physics
column2: optical depth or optical thickness is the natural logarithm of the ratio of incident to transmitted radiant power through a material.Thus
column3: the larger the optical depth
column4: the smaller the amount of transmitted radiant power through the material. Spectral optical depth or spectral optical thickness is the natural logarithm of the ratio of incident to transmitted spectral radiant power through a material. Optical depth is dimensionless

column1: The Duchy of Anjou ( , ; ; ) was a French province straddling the lower river Loire . Its capital was Tours, and it included much of the region that is now central France . Anjou () is derived from the Latin , Anseis meaning "mouth of the River Loire" (from which Anjou was originally separated). The region of Anjou is bounded on the east by the Massif Central to the north by Brittany and to the west by Saintonge and the River Charente. In English, Anjou is sometimes used to describe parts of Touraine, Loiret and Sarthe.|0

J. Robert Oppenheimer (; April 22, 1904 – February 18, 1967) was an American theoretical physicist who was professor of physics at the University of California, Berkeley. Oppenheimer was the wartime head of the Los Alamos Laboratory and is among those who are credited with being the "father of the atomic bomb" for their role in the Manhattan Project – the World War II undertaking that developed the first nuclear weapons. Oppenheimer was among those who observed the Trinity test in New Mexico, where the first atomic bomb was successfully detonated on July 16, 1945.|1

column1: Spins are an element in figure skating in which the skater rotates, centered on a single point on the ice, while holding one or more body positions. Battle of Flodden
1494: The Battle of Flodden occurs on the Northumbrian coast in England. The battle of Flodden was fought between the Scots under king James IV and a joint English-Hanoverian force under the earl of Surrey. The battle began on 9 September and ended in victory for the English. The Scottish forces were heavily defeated and the surviving Scottish King was captured. The battle of Flodden is a famous victory of the Anglo-Scots over a larger Scottish army in the War of the Roses.|0

A battering ram is a siege engine that originated in ancient times and was designed to break open the masonry walls of fortifications or splinter their wooden gates. In its simplest form
column2: a battering ram is just a large
column3: heavy log carried by several people and propelled with force against an obstacle; the ram would be sufficient to damage the target if the log were massive enough and/or it were moved quickly enough (that is
column4: if it had enough momentum). Later rams encased the log in an arrow-proof
column5: fire-resistant canopy mounted on wheels. Inside the canopy
column6: the log was swung from suspensory chains or ropes.|1

The tale of the founding of Rome is recounted in traditional stories handed down by the ancient Romans themselves as well as by later writers such as Livy. Although a number of these stories contradict one another, there are several elements common to the various versions of the story:

The city of Rome was founded by Aeneas (Aenus in Greek), the son of the god Apollo and the goddess Latona, and grandson of Aeneas. In the most traditional version of the Roman myth, Aeneas was the founder of a city in Latium, where his descendants (the Romans) became a powerful and successful people.|0

column1: Freestyle skiing is a  skiing discipline comprising aerials, moguls, cross, half-pipe, slopestyle and big air as part of the Winter Olympics. It can consist of a skier performing aerial flips and spins and can include skiers sliding rails and boxes on their skis. Known as "hot-dogging" in the early 1970s, it is also commonly referred to as freeskiing, jibbing, as well as many other names, around the world.History Ski acrobatics have been practiced since the 1930s/1940s. Aerial skiing was popularized in the 1950s by Olympic gold medalist Stein Eriksen. Early US competitions were held in the mid-1960s.|1

Panettone ( , ; ) is an Italian type of sweet bread originally from Milan , usually prepared and enjoyed in Italy around Christmas and Easter time. The word is believed to have evolved from Panetti (from  ) "little loaves (or panes)", and was originally a variant name for panforte , a traditional Italian type of sweet bread, possibly made from dried fruit, honey and/or almonds. [1] The word panettone is first attested in print in 1498. The panettone is a traditional Italian Christmas bread. It is very soft, sweet, sticky and moist inside.|0

column1: The Zwinger  is a palatial complex with gardens in Dresden, Germany. Designed by architect Matthäus Daniel Pöppelmann, it is one of the most important buildings of the Baroque period in Germany. Along with the Frauenkirche, the Zwinger is the most famous architectural monument of Dresden. The name "Zwinger" goes back to the name used in the Middle Ages for a fortress part between the outer and inner fortress walls, even though the Zwinger no longer had a function corresponding to the name at the start of construction.The Zwinger was built in 1709 as an orangery and garden as well as a representative festival area.|1

column2: the central limit theorem (CLT) establishes that
column3: in many situations
column4: when independent random variables are summed up
column5: their properly normalized sum tends toward a normal distribution (informally a bell curve) even if the original variables themselves are not normally distributed. The theorem is a key concept in probability theory because it implies that probabilistic and statistical methods that work for normal distributions can be applicable to many problems involving other types of distributions. This theorem has seen many changes during the formal development of probability theory.|1

column1: Lillian Evelyn Gilbreth ( Moller; May 24, 1878 – January 2, 1972) was an American psychologist, industrial engineer, consultant, and educator who was an early pioneer in applying psychology to time-and-motion studies. Mercia (, ; ) was one of the kingdoms of the Anglo-Saxon Heptarchy. The name is a Latinisation of the Old English  or  (West Saxon dialect;  in the Mercian dialect itself), meaning "border people" (see March). Mercia dominated what would later become England for three centuries, subsequently going into a gradual decline while Wessex eventually conquered and united all the kingdoms into the Kingdom of England.The kingdom was centred on the valley of the River Trent and its tributaries, in the region now known as the English Midlands. The court moved around the kingdom, and there was no fixed capital city.|1

column1: Poltava ( , ; ) is a city located on the Vorskla River in central Ukraine . It is the administrative center of Poltava oblast and the administrative center of Poltava urban okrug . The name Poltava is of Slavonic origin; the earliest known written mention of the city dates to 918 CE. In the past, Poltava was known as the "City of the Black Army" for its role during the Cossack Uprising. Poltava is a city of about 100,000 people (2010 estimate). It is an important industrial, agricultural and transportation center of central Ukraine, with a population increase of nearly 25% since 1991.|0

The sousaphone  is a brass instrument in the same family as the more widely known tuba. Created around 1893 by J.W. Pepper at the direction of American bandleader John Philip Sousa (after whom the instrument was then named), it was designed to be easier to play than the concert tuba while standing or marching, as well as to carry the sound of the instrument above the heads of the band. Like the tuba, sound is produced by moving air past the lips, causing them to vibrate or "buzz" into a large cupped mouthpiece.|1

 April 8 – Emperor John VIII Zaimichi is assassinated, along with his chief eunuch (spatharios). He is replaced by Patriarch Theophilos. John is murdered in his sleep at the Hippodrome in Constantinople; his cousin Michael III is chosen as emperor. John VIII's widow Irene becomes co-emperor, but she is forced to cede most of the power to a younger brother, Nikephoros III.|0

Bacillus cereus is a Gram-positive, rod-shaped, facultatively anaerobic, motile, beta-hemolytic, spore-forming bacterium commonly found in soil, food and marine sponges. The specific name, cereus, meaning "waxy" in Latin, refers to the appearance of colonies grown on blood agar. Some strains are harmful to humans and cause foodborne illness, while other strains can be beneficial as probiotics for animals. The bacteria is classically contracted from fried rice dishes that have been sitting at room temperature for hours. B. cereus bacteria are facultative anaerobes, and like other members of the genus Bacillus, can produce protective endospores.|1

column1: Robert I Estienne (; 15037 September 1559), known as Robertus Stephanus in Latin and sometimes referred to as Robert Stephens, was a 16th-century printer and classical scholar in Paris. He was the proprietor of the Estienne print shop after the death of his father Henri Estienne, the founder of the Estienne printing firm. Estienne published and republished many classical texts as well as Greek and Latin translations of the Bible. Known as "Printer to the King" in Latin, Hebrew, and Greek, Estienne's most prominent work was the Thesaurus linguae latinae which is considered to be the foundation of modern Latin lexicography.|1

column1: Proline (symbol Pro or P) is an organic acid classed as a proteinogenic amino acid (used in the biosynthesis of proteins), although it does not contain the amino group  but is rather a secondary amine. The secondary amine nitrogen is in the protonated NH2+ form under biological conditions, while the carboxyl group is in the deprotonated −COO− form. The "side chain" from the α carbon connects to the nitrogen forming a pyrrolidine loop, classifying it as a aliphatic amino acid. It is non-essential in humans, meaning the body can synthesize it from the non-essential amino acid L-glutamate.|1

The year is best known for the Gunpowder Treason Plot of Guy Fawkes, to blow up the Houses of Parliament on 5 November and kill King James I and most of his court. It has been suggested that the "Gunpowder Plot" name is derived from Guy Fawkes' last name as a variant of Guido (Italian for John). The plot failed as all of the conspirators were arrested and their names revealed to Parliament before the plot was complete.|0

Hide-and-seek is a popular children's game in which at least two players (usually at least three) conceal themselves in a set environment, to be found by one or more seekers. The game is played by one chosen player (designated as being "it") counting to a predetermined number with eyes closed while the other players hide. After reaching this number, the player who is "it" calls "Ready or not, here I come!" or "Coming, ready or not!" and then attempts to locate all concealed players.The game can end in one of several ways.|1

The foreign relations of Albania are its relations with other governments and peoples. Foreign relations are conducted through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Tirana. The current Ambassador to the United Nations is Besiana Kadare.Albania is a sovereign country in Southern Europe and the Mediterranean that declared its independence on 28 November 1912. Year 1396 ( MCCCXCVI ) was a leap year starting on Saturday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. Pope John XXIII ( 1835 – 1958 )

Pope John XXIII ( 1835 – 1958 ), born Angelo Giuseppe Roncalli, was Pope from 1939 to 1958. During his long papacy he became a key figure in the Catholic Church after the war, as well as having a considerable impact on contemporary society and political affairs, as a result of his social liberalism, his openness to ecumenism, his criticism of the Soviet Union, his support for democracy and his efforts to unite the Catholic world.|0

In the performing arts, a scenario (, ; from Italian: "that which is pinned to the scenery", ) is a synoptical collage of an event or series of actions and events. In the commedia dell'arte it was an outline of entrances, exits, and action describing the plot of a play, and was literally pinned to the back of the scenery. It is also known as canovaccio  or "that which is pinned to the canvas" of which the scenery was constructed.Surviving scenarios from the Renaissance contain little other than character names, brief descriptions of action, and references to specific lazzi with no further explanation.|1

The Cross of Gold speech was delivered by William Jennings Bryan , a former United States Representative from Nebraska , at the 1896 Democratic National Convention. The address, given as part of his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, was a famous campaign speech that helped win the election for the Democrats in November that year. It was a rallying cry for his supporters to unite behind the Democratic Party. It was delivered on July 17, 1896 in Chicago before a crowd of over 100,000 people. Bryan opened his speech with a prayer and asked the Almighty to "bless and preserve this great land, our native home."|0

A noble savage is a literary stock character who embodies the concept of the indigene , outsider , wild human , or primitive man . This archetype originated in Europe during the Renaissance , where the "noblesse oblige" notion of chivalrous service to others was combined with ideas about savages in Africa or the Americas. Some of these stereotypes are racist or misogynistic, and in modern times the noble savage has generally been associated with primitivism . Characteristics 

 Noble savage is typically a member of a different racial group than the "civilized" population.|0

OS-9 is a family of real-time , process-based , multitasking , multi-user operating systems , developed in the 1980s , and is a descendant of the original Plan 9 operating system. Initially developed as a replacement for the original BSD Unix operating system , it was designed to be a research operating system in the vein of the original UNIX, and is often cited as one of the first real-time operating systems. As an extension of the Plan 9 philosophy, a number of features are implemented to aid system development:



Each process is represented by a separate process image.|0

column1: In computer programming , a postcondition is a condition or predicate that must always be true just after the execution of an algorithm, and that may be either asserted or inferred. The term "postcondition" was introduced by Peter Naur as a condition to be checked before the program execution in the context of a program that can fail. A postcondition is typically used to make the program developer's intentions more obvious. It is usually written as a list of sentences, each sentence being the result of a postcondition clause. This list is often called a postcondition specification .|0

The 15th century was a century that lasted from 1499 through 1599. It was the century of the earliest surviving printed books, of Johannes Gutenbergs movable type, of the first translations of the Latin classics into European vernacular, the Italian Renaissance, and the birth of science as a separate subject in Europe.|0

The Quirinal Hill ( ; ; ) is one of the Seven Hills of Rome , at the north-east of the city. It rises to  and is  in diameter at its summit. The hill was first conquered by Rome during the 7th century BC and from then on became a symbol of imperial glory and the residence of the emperors for centuries. The hill was later the seat of the popes. Location

The Quirinal Hill is named after a tribe (Qirinus) which inhabited the hills in Etruria, near what is now Poggio Reale and Castello di Sotto. It was the residence of the Etruscans and Romans.|0

column5: the Hubble Space Telescope has been used mainly for astronomical observations.|0

A total of 70% of the town's land area is under protection, and nearly half of it is part of the Cape Cod National Seashore. column1: Digital electronics  is a field of electronics involving the study of digital signals and the engineering of devices that use or produce them. This is in contrast to analog electronics and analog signals.Digital electronic circuits are usually made from large assemblies of logic gates

column3: the principles of arithmetic and logic could be joined. Digital logic as we know it was the brain-child of George Boole in the mid 19th century.|1

column1: An oak is a tree or shrub in the genus Quercus ( ; Latin `` oak tree '' ) of the family Fagaceae, native to temperate regions of the world. [1] The scientific name comes from the Latin and Greek words for "maple-tree". Although the oaks form a diverse group, all but two members are trees and many grow to a height of 45–150 m (150–500 ft) and occasionally to about 300 m (1000 ft).|0

column1: In art history, literature and cultural studies, Orientalism is the imitation or depiction of aspects in the Eastern world. These depictions are usually done by writers, designers, and artists from the Western world. In particular, Orientalist painting, depicting more specifically "the Middle East", was one of the many specialisms of 19th-century academic art, and the literature of Western countries took a similar interest in Oriental themes.Since the publication of Edward Said's Orientalism in 1978, much academic discourse has begun to use the term "Orientalism" to refer to a general patronizing Western attitude towards Middle Eastern, Asian, and North African societies.|1

column1: A domain name is an identification string that defines a realm of administrative autonomy

column1: Arthrobacter (from the Greek, "jointed small stick”) is a genus of bacteria that is commonly found in soil. All species in this genus are Gram-positive obligate aerobes that are rods during exponential growth and cocci in their stationary phase. Arthrobacter have a distinctive method of cell division called "snapping division" or reversion in which the outer bacterial cell wall ruptures at a joint.DescriptionArthrobacter can be grown on mineral salts pyridone broth, where colonies have a greenish metallic center on incubated at . Under the microscope, Arthrobacter appear as rods when rapidly dividing, and cocci when in stationary phase.|1

column1: The Cape Cod Canal is an artificial waterway in the U.S. state of Massachusetts connecting Cape Cod Bay in the South with Buzzards Bay in the North
column2: and separating Massachusetts and New Hampshire. The canal runs through the towns of Orleans and Eastham in Barnstable County and was constructed between 1915 and 1917 to provide access from the Atlantic Ocean to New Bedford Harbor on the North Atlantic Coast. The canal provides a shipping link from Boston to the New England ports in the north
column3: and was constructed to allow commercial traffic to bypass a shallow and winding portion of Massachusetts Bay.|0

3.1 Inscriptions

1250 was marked with many important events in history. The 1250th year of the Christian era is widely known for the Battle of Hastings in England where the Norman William the Bastard defeated and killed King Harold Godwin. In 1250 also, Pope Innocent IV began the first General Council of the Roman Church. He died on June 9 of that year in 1254.|0
Roger Williams ( 21 December 1603between 27 January and 15 March 1683 ) was a Puritan minister
column2: theologian
column3: and theologian . He founded the Massachusetts Bay colony with fellow minister John Winthrop the Younger
column4: in New Netherland
column5: which became the present-day state of Rhode Island
column6: in the New World
column7: in 1636 . He later became president of Harvard University after the passing of William Brattle. He was the only child and the eldest son of Anne Hutchinson and the Rev. John Williams. His father was the only son of Anne Hutchinson and the Rev. Nicholas Rogers.|0

Year 1051 ( MLI ) was a common year starting on Tuesday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. The year is considered a common year starting on Tuesday because it has only 354 or 355 days, with an error of three days, the Julian leap day, inserted in February 1548. It is also the year 981 BC. Contents

On November 23, 1051, the king of the West Saxons, Æthelred I, died after a reign of 25 years, and Cnut took over. England and the rest of Europe was now in turmoil, with half the population probably starving.|0

A playwright or dramatist is a person who writes plays.EtymologyThe word `` play '' is from Middle English pleye
column2: from Old English plei
column3: probably from the Old Norse pleya
column4: plega . It is a cognate of German Spiel and Middle Dutch pla . Plei- (pleigh
column5: plural pleighen) has two related meanings. The past participle means `` played '' and the past participle is still used for `` playing the flute
column6: '' as in `` He played the flute '' . The Middle Low German word was pronounced plega or ploga . The Middle English verb `` play '' is recorded from 1375.|0

column1: Georgy Konstantinovich Zhukov (; ; 1 December 1896 – 18 June 1974) was a Soviet general and Marshal of the Soviet Union. He also served as Chief of the General Staff
column2: Minister of Defence
column3: and was a member of the Presidium of the Communist Party (later Politburo). During the Second World War
column4: Zhukov oversaw some of the Red Army's most decisive victories.Born to a poor peasant family from central Russia
column5: Zhukov was conscripted into the Imperial Russian Army and fought in the First World War. He served in the Red Army during the Russian Civil War.|1

column1: Figure skating jumps are an element of three competitive figure skating disciplines—men 's singles
column2: ladies ' singles
column3: and pairs —and have evolved in different ways in the sport. Jumping skills have remained largely the same
column4: except in one important aspect — the way the skater's height is calculated. The way in which jumping is assessed in figure skating has changed many times
column5: and the jumps themselves have been altered over time
column6: as the technical requirements of the various disciplines have changed. This page discusses the history of jump assessments in figure skating and the evolution of jumps.|0

column1: A killer is someone or something that kills

column3: but a murder
column4: or murder in plural is singular. The plural murder can also be used as the word murder is a short form of murders . When you use the word killer
column5: or killers in plural
column6: make sure you use an apostrophe
column7: as shown. Killer or killers is singular . When you are dealing with the word murder
column8: or murders
column9: you must use the plural. In the United States
column10: the legal definition of murder is a killing that is unlawful .|0

column1: Lazzi (; from the Italian lazzo
column2: a joke or witticism) are stock comedic routines that are associated with Commedia dell'arte. Performers
column3: especially those playing the masked Arlecchino
column4: had many examples of this in their repertoire
column5: and would use improvisatory skills to weave them into the plot of dozens of different commedia scenarios. These largely physical sequences could be improvised or preplanned within the performance and were often used to enliven the audience when a scene was dragging
column6: to cover a dropped line or cue
column7: or to delight an expectant audience with the troupe's specialized lazzi.Lazzi could be completed by a single player (e.g.|1

column1: The Battle of Trafalgar (21 October 1805) was a naval engagement between the British Royal Navy and the combined fleets of the French and Spanish Navies during the War of the Third Coalition (August–December 1805) of the Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815).As part of Napoleon's plans to invade England
column2: the French and Spanish fleets combined to take control of the English Channel and provide the Grande Armée safe passage. The allied fleet
column3: under the command of French Admiral Villeneuve
column4: sailed from the port of Cádiz in the south of Spain on 18 October 1805.|1

column1: The European bison ( Bison bonasus ) or the European wood bison
column2: also known as the wisent ( or ) is a large wild ungulate that became extinct in Europe by the beginning of the nineteenth century and is now found solely in Ukraine
column3: Belarus and Lithuania. Although bison are found throughout Europe and Asia
column4: they are considered endangered and protected by EU law. The bison once lived across northern Europe
column5: from Russia to Ireland
column6: and across most of continental Europe. However
column7: due to human interference and habitat loss
column8: they are now almost extinct.|0

column1: English Renaissance theatre, also known as Renaissance English theatre and Elizabethan theatre, refers to the theatre of England between 1558 and 1642.This is the style of the plays of William Shakespeare, Christopher Marlowe and Ben Jonson.BackgroundThe term English Renaissance theatre encompasses the period between 1562—following a performance of Gorboduc, the first English play using blank verse, at the Inner Temple during the Christmas season of 1561—and the ban on theatrical plays enacted by the English Parliament in 1642.The phrase Elizabethan theatre is sometimes improperly used to mean English Renaissance theatre, although in a strict sense "Elizabethan" only refers to the period of Queen Elizabeth's reign (1558–1603).|1

A Tesla coil is an electrical resonant transformer circuit designed by inventor Nikola Tesla in 1891. It is used to produce high-voltage
column2: low-current
column3: high frequency alternating-current electricity. Tesla experimented with a number of different configurations consisting of two
column4: or sometimes three
column5: coupled resonant electric circuits.Tesla used these circuits to conduct innovative experiments in electrical lighting
column6: phosphorescence
column7: X-ray generation
column8: high frequency alternating current phenomena
column9: electrotherapy
column10: and the transmission of electrical energy without wires. Tesla coil circuits were used commercially in sparkgap radio transmitters for wireless telegraphy until the 1920s
column11: and in medical equipment such as electrotherapy and violet ray devices.|1

column1: Year 1212 ( MCCXII ) was a leap year starting on Sunday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. Note that the Gregorian Calendar (which becomes compulsory in Britain in 1752 ) and the Julian Calendar are different but they agree for dates before 10 September 1582 AD. The Common Calendar ( adopted by most of Europe from 1583 AD) had its origin in 1582/83 with the reform of Gregory XIII. For dates before the Gregorian Reforms the Common or Old Calendar is in use until now
column2: in countries such as Spain or the Eastern Orthodox and Roman Catholic churches.|0

column1: The French and Indian War ( 1754–1763 ) was a theater of the Seven Years ' War
column2: which pitted France and Great Britain in an effort to gain predominance of the North American colonies. Following the 1748 outbreak of war between France and Great Britain
column3: the conflict rapidly expanded to a global dimension. French forces attempted to colonize Canada
column4: attack British outposts in the western United States and acquire the Louisiana Territory
column5: a territory lying between the Gulf of Mexico and the Appalachians . Britain also sought control over the area in an effort to keep the newly acquired colony of Spanish Florida from expanding its influence into the area.|0

She is the mother and regent of 12-year-old Emperor Alexios II. In August, Andronikos Komnenos, a cousin of Maria's late husband, Emperor Manuel I (Komnenos), raises an army and enters the city, representing himself as the 'protector' of Alexios.|1

Panettone (
column2: ;  ) is an Italian type of sweet bread originally from Milan

column1: Ski jumping is a winter sport in which competitors aim to achieve the farthest jump after sliding down on their skis from a specially designed curved ramp. Along with jump length
column2: competitor's aerial style and other factors also affect the final score. Ski jumping was first contested in Norway in the late 19th century

column4: it constitutes the traditional group of Nordic skiing disciplines.The ski jumping venue
column5: commonly referred to as a hill
column6: consists of the jumping ramp (in-run)
column7: take-off table
column8: and a landing hill.|1

column1: Johan August Arfwedson (12 January 1792 – 28 October 1841) was a  Swedish chemist who discovered the chemical element lithium in 1817 by isolating it as a salt.Life and work Arfwedson belonged to a wealthy bourgeois family

column1: Natural science is one of the branches of science concerned with the description
column2: understanding and prediction of natural phenomena

Mechanisms such as peer review and repeatability of findings are used to try to ensure the validity of scientific advances.Natural science can be divided into two main branches: life science and physical science. Life science is alternatively known as biology

column5: chemistry
column6: earth science
column7: and astronomy. These branches of natural science may be further divided into more specialized branches (also known as fields).|1

column1:

Frederick Barbarossa (1122 – 10 June 1190), also known as Frederick I , was the Holy Roman Emperor from 1155 until his death 35 years later. He was elected King of Germany at Frankfurt on 4 March 1152 and crowned in Aachen on 9 March 1152. He was crowned King of Italy on 24 April 1155 in Pavia and emperor by Pope Adrian IV on 18 June 1155 in Rome. Two years later, the term  ("holy") first appeared in a document in connection with his empire. He was later formally crowned King of Burgundy, at Arles on 30 June 1178.|1

1290 is considered to be an important year in the history of the Oyo Empire. This is because, for the first time in over 300 years, it would not be ruled by a child of the Atabey royal family, and it would usher in the first major change in Oyo Empire politics for nearly a century. Atabey I, son of the previous emperor, died on 25 October 1289, during his reign of almost 20 years.|0

column1: The Witan, literally "wise men", was the king's council in Anglo-Saxon England from before the seventh century until the 11th century. It was composed of the leading magnates, both ecclesiastic and secular, and meetings of the council were sometimes called the Witenagemot. Its primary function was to advise the king on subjects such as promulgation of laws, judicial judgments, approval of charters transferring land, settlement of disputes, election of archbishops and bishops and other matters of major national importance. The witan also had to elect and approve the appointment of a new king.|1

Epicureanism is a system of philosophy founded around 307 BC based upon the teachings of the ancient Greek philosopher Epicurus. Epicureanism was originally a challenge to Platonism. Later its main opponent became Stoicism.Few writings by Epicurus have survived. However
column2: there are independent attestations of his ideas from his later disciples. Some scholars consider the epic poem De rerum natura (Latin for On the Nature of Things) by Lucretius to present in one unified work the core arguments and theories of Epicureanism. Many of the scrolls unearthed at the Villa of the Papyri at Herculaneum are Epicurean texts.|1

column1: Banksia is a genus of around 170 species in the plant family Proteaceae . These Australian wildflowers and popular garden plants share the distinction of being the most threatened flora in the world. It is currently considered to have the highest level of endangerment on the IUCN red list
column2: with at least half the species assessed as threatened or near threatened and at least half of that number as endangered . Banksia
column3: commonly known as willow banksias
column4: are found throughout the temperate regions of Australia
column5: and in a number of nearby island territories. They are usually small shrubs
column6: but some grow into large trees reaching up to 30 m high.|0

column3: when it held the name People's Party
column4: although its name was changed to the present one in 1903. During the Second Polish Republic
column5: the Polish People's Party was represented by a number of parties that held its name. They were all supportive of agrarian policies
column6: although they spanned from the left-wing to the centre-right on the political spectrum. It was reformed into the People's Party shortly after the Sanacja regime took power.|1
