column5: who was concerned that the Admiralty and other departments were becoming too powerful and were taking the lead in government decisions.|0

column1: Gravity
column2: or gravitation
column3: is a natural phenomenon by which all things with mass or energy
column4: including planets
column5: stars
column6: galaxies and even light
column7: are attracted to (or gravitate toward) one another. On Earth
column8: gravity gives weight to physical objects
column9: and the Moon's gravity causes the tides of the oceans. The gravitational attraction of the original gaseous matter present in the Universe caused it to begin coalescing and forming stars and caused the stars to group together into galaxies
column10: so gravity is responsible for many of the large-scale structures in the Universe.|1

column1: Provincetown  is a New England town located at the extreme tip of Cape Cod in Barnstable County, Massachusetts, in the United States. A small coastal resort town with a year-round population of 3,664 as of the 2020 United States Census, Provincetown has a summer population as high as 60,000. Often called "P-town" or "P'town", the locale is known for its beaches, harbor, artists, tourist industry, and as a popular vacation destination for the LGBT+ community.History At the time of European encounter, the area was long settled by the historic Nauset tribe, who had a settlement known as "Meeshawn".|1

Operetta is a form of theatre and a genre of light opera. It includes spoken dialogue, songs, and dances. It is lighter than opera in terms of its music, orchestral size, length of the work, and at face value, subject matter. Apart from its shorter length, the operetta is usually of a light and amusing character. It sometimes also includes satirical commentaries. "Operetta" is the Italian diminutive of "opera" and was used originally to describe a shorter, perhaps less ambitious work than an opera. Operetta provides an alternative to operatic performances in an accessible form targeting a different audience.|1

Tone is the use of pitch in language to distinguish lexical or grammatical meaning – that is , to distinguish the meanings in the language from those of the same words in different languages. Tone can distinguish words that sound similar; it is an integral part of Chinese linguistics. This page gives a few samples of tones used in Chinese. (For tone in other languages, see this page.) A very basic overview of tones

Chinese is tonal (that is , it distinguishes words by tone) because it has tones. In a language with tones, tones distinguish words.|0

column1: The sousaphone is a brass instrument in the same family as the more widely known tuba . Created around 1893
column2: its sound is similar in timbre to the tuba
column3: but the sousaphone has a somewhat thinner body. The sousaphone was originally intended for military bands. In the late nineteenth century
column4: there was a movement to make brass instruments more accessible to amateurs. In 1885
column5: in response to this need
column6: the instrument-maker J. S. Bronson created a new instrument: the sousaphone . This instrument has a larger bell and larger valves than a traditional tuba; the sousaphone became widely popular for military bands.|0

column1: Photomontage is the process and the result of making a composite photograph by cutting, gluing, rearranging and overlapping two or more photographs into a new image. Sometimes the resulting composite image is photographed so that the final image may appear as a seamless physical print. A similar method, although one that does not use film, is realized today through image-editing software. This latter technique is referred to by professionals as "compositing", and in casual usage is often called "photoshopping" (from the name of the popular software system).|1

column1: Vapor pressure (or vapour pressure in English-speaking counties other than the US; see spelling differences) or equilibrium vapor pressure is defined as the pressure exerted by a vapor in thermodynamic equilibrium with its condensed phases (solid or liquid) at a given temperature in a closed system. The equilibrium vapor pressure is an indication of a liquid's evaporation rate. It relates to the tendency of particles to escape from the liquid (or a solid). A substance with a high vapor pressure at normal temperatures is often referred to as volatile. The pressure exhibited by vapor present above a liquid surface is known as vapor pressure.|1

column1: In computer programming
column2: a postcondition is a condition or predicate that must always be true just after the execution of some section of code or after an operation in a formal specification. Postconditions are sometimes tested using assertions within the code itself. Often
column3: postconditions are simply included in the documentation of the affected section of code.For example: The result of a factorial is always an integer and greater than or equal to 1. So a program that calculates the factorial of an input number would have postconditions that the result after the calculation be an integer and that it be greater than or equal to 1.|1

A sifaka is a lemur of the genus Propithecus from the family Indriidae within the order Primates . The name is a combination of ‘ sifaka, ‘ meaning lemur in the Swahili language , and the genus Propithecus from the ancient Greek word “propheteos,” meaning foreteller . Description

The sifaka has an average height of , with a range of from  in males to  in females. Adult sifaka males typically have a head and body weight of , with a tail that weighs . The tail length of a sifaka is from . The tail helps to balance the larger head of the lemur.|0

In physics , quintessence is a hypothetical form of dark energy , more precisely a scalar field , postulated as an evolving fluid to model the accelerated expansion of the universe. The name comes from the idea that it is a "fifth force" that permeates everything. In other words, unlike ordinary matter (e.g. dust), it is not subject to Newtonian gravity, and unlike dark matter , it cannot be detected via gravitational effects. It is hypothesized that dark energy will dominate the energy content of the universe in its future expansion phase.|0

Dissociative identity disorder (DID)
column2: previously known as multiple personality disorder (MPD)
column3: is a mental disorder characterized by the maintenance of at least two distinct and relatively enduring personality states. The disorder is accompanied by memory gaps beyond what would be explained by ordinary memory issues. The personality states alternately show in a person's behavior; however
column4: presentations of the disorder vary. Other conditions that often occur in people with DID include post-traumatic stress disorder
column5: personality disorders (especially borderline and avoidant)
column6: depression
column7: substance use disorders
column8: conversion disorder
column9: somatic symptom disorder
column10: eating disorders
column12: and sleep disorders.|1

column9: such as the hands

Bdellovibrio is a genus of Gram-negative, obligate aerobic bacterium. One of the more notable characteristics of this genus is that members can prey upon other Gram-negative bacteria and feed on the biopolymers, e.g. proteins and nucleic acids, of their hosts. They have two lifestyles: a host-dependent, highly mobile phase, the "attack phase", in which they form "bdelloplasts" in their host bacteria; and a slow-growing, irregularly shaped, host-independent form.Bdellovibrio bacteriovorusThe most well studied of these is Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus, which is found almost exclusively in host dependent growth in nature.|1

column1: In computational complexity theory
column2: PSPACE is the set of all decision problems that can be solved by a Turing machine using a stack that grows only finitely often
column3: which is to say that the machine can only use the stack for a bounded number of steps
column4: and then the stack is allowed to shrink in some controlled way. Thus
column5: the computational complexity of many mathematical problems can be specified in terms of their time complexity
column6: which is the number of steps required to compute a solution by a Turing machine
column7: and not the time required to compute a solution by physical means.|0

column4: but not all languages use tones to distinguish words or their inflections
column5: analogously to consonants and vowels. Languages that have this feature are called tonal languages; the distinctive tone patterns of such a language are sometimes called tonemes

An engagement ring is a ring indicating that the person wearing it is engaged to be married, especially in Western cultures. A ring is presented as an engagement gift by a partner to their prospective spouse when they propose marriage or directly after a marriage proposal is accepted. It represents a formal agreement to future marriage. In Western countries, engagement rings are worn mostly by women, and rings can feature diamonds or other gemstones. The neologism "mangagement ring" is sometimes used for an engagement ring worn by men. In some cultures, men and women wear matching rings, and engagement rings may also be used as wedding rings.|1

Slapstick is a style of humor involving exaggerated physical activity that exceeds the boundaries of normal physical comedy. Slapstick may involve both intentional violence and violence by mishap, often resulting from inept use of props such as saws and ladders. The term arises from a device developed for use in the broad, physical comedy style known as commedia dell'arte in 16th-century Italy. The "slap stick" consists of two thin slats of wood, which make a "slap" when striking another actor, with little force needed to make a loud—and comical—sound.|1

column1: Business is the activity of making one's living or making money by producing or buying and selling products (such as goods and services). Simply put, it is "any activity or enterprise entered into for profit. "Having a business name does not separate the business entity from the owner, which means that the owner of the business is responsible and liable for debts incurred by the business. If the business acquires debts, the creditors can go after the owner's personal possessions. A business structure does not allow for corporate tax rates.|1

column1: The Battle of Trafalgar ( 21 October 1805 ) was a naval engagement between the British Royal Navy and the Spanish Navy. It took place between 19 and 22 October in the Bay of Cadiz between a small squadron of British and French frigates and a much larger force of Spanish warships. Trafalgar is named after the island of Trafalgar in the Spanish province of Cadiz. Trafalgar is said to have been a 'victory of the immortals' because none of the French or Spanish ships were sunk
column2: but the Spanish ships ran aground and became prizes.|0

A semi-automatic rifle is an autoloading rifle that fires one round each pull of the trigger . For comparison
column2: the same gun in full auto mode can fire dozens of rounds per pull. A fully automatic fire-rate is considered high-volume
column3: and can be achieved using a fully automatic firearm
column4: which will automatically reload when the magazine is exhausted. High-volume semi-automatic fire rates are considered lower-volume . The term is sometimes incorrectly used in other contexts
column5: including in reference to high-capacity magazines
column6: which contain more than the legal minimum number of rounds for the weapon.|0

column1: It is one of eight years ( CE ) to contain each Roman numeral exactly once ( 1000 ( M) ), except for 2, which is never followed by a period. In the year 1000 of the Common Era or Common Era, the first day of the month of December was the beginning of a new year, rather than the first day of January. The day of the new year was a day to give thanks or to celebrate, which is why it is called " New Years Day " in English and the New Year's Holiday in the Chinese language.|0

Bamboos are a diverse group of evergreen perennial flowering plants in the subfamily Bambusoideae of the grass family Poaceae. Giant bamboos are the largest members of the grass family. The origin of the word "bamboo" is uncertain, but it probably comes from the Dutch or Portuguese language, which originally borrowed it from Malay or Kannada.In bamboo, as in other grasses, the internodal regions of the stem are usually hollow and the vascular bundles in the cross-section are scattered throughout the stem instead of in a cylindrical arrangement. The dicotyledonous woody xylem is also absent.|1

Michelangelo Antonioni ( , ; 29 September 1912 – 30 July 2007 ) was an Italian film director , screenwriter , poet , painter , and actor . In 1960 , Antonioni wrote and directed his first feature , L'avventura ( , The Adventure ). He was nominated for a Golden Globe Award as Best Director and won the Palme d'Or at the 1963 Cannes Film Festival for L'avventura and again in 1964 for La Notte. He was awarded the Academy Honorary Award in 1987. Antonioni produced two operas and three ballets. Contents

Early life

Antonioni was born Mario Antonioni in Turin , Italy .|0

A noble savage is a literary stock character who embodies the concept of the indigene, outsider, wild human, an "other" who has not been "corrupted" by civilization, and therefore symbolizes humanity's innate goodness. Besides appearing in many works of fiction and philosophy, the stereotype was also heavily employed in early anthropological works.In English, the phrase first appeared in the 17th century in John Dryden's heroic play The Conquest of Granada (1672), wherein it was used in reference to newly created man. "Savage" at that time could mean "wild beast" as well as "wild man".|1

column1: A Roman villa was typically a farmhouse or country house built in the Roman Republic and the Roman Empire , but in the 4th and 5th century, many were also made into mansions or even palaces. The term "villa" is probably derived from vīlle, meaning "wheel", in this case an open circle, the wheel and circle being symbols in Etruscan religion. By the 4th and 5th century, however, it was no longer merely a farmhouse; villas, like the rest of Roman civilization, began to reflect the increasing wealth and luxury of the ruling classes.|0

column1: A battering ram is a siege engine that originated in ancient times and was designed to break open the masonry of castles and fortifications to enable siege engineers to pour in fire or to demolish the interior of the fortifications. They were typically built of heavy oak timbers

column3: as well as later in the 17th century during the era of European wars of attrition. They remained in common usage until well into the 20th century
column4: with some still in service today.|0

Events

January 1 – King Alfonso XI of Aragon takes Barcelona, ending a siege which has lasted more than seven months. column1: The Stoned Guest is a "half-act opera" by Peter Schickele in the satirical persona of P. D. Q. Bach. The title is a play on the "stone guest" character in Don Giovanni by Mozart, as well as the opera The Stone Guest by Alexander Sergeyevich Dargomïzhsky after the play by Pushkin. The work is a parody of classical opera, although some critics consider it to be the equal of many classical works in technical ability. The opera appears on the 1970 album of the same name.The loose story combines elements of Don Giovanni with elements of Carmen by Georges Bizet.|1

column1: A pine is any conifer tree or shrub in the genus Pinus of the family Pinaceae . Pinus is the common name for the genus of coniferous trees and is the only genus of evergreen trees in the family Pinaceae. It includes such familiar trees as pines

column5: reaching 50 cm or more in length and width.|0

column4: or bamboo family. They are usually treated in the grasses as a tribe or a subtribe
column5: as for instance in the APG IV system. The group's most common members are bamboo ( Bambusa ) and the grasses (Poaceae). Other well-known bamboos include sugarcane (Saccharum)
column6: and a number of grasses are used for food or fiber.|0

Pope Urban IV, whose name in Latin is Urbanus IV. (1261–64), was a Franciscan. He is best remembered for the Councils of Urban IV, the Second Council of the Lateran, and the Third Council of the Lateran.|0
A Roman villa was typically a farmhouse or country house built in the Roman Republic and the Roman Empire
column2: sometimes reaching extravagant proportions.Typology and distributionPliny the Elder (23–79 AD) distinguished two kinds of villas near Rome: the villa urbana
column3: a country seat that could easily be reached from Rome (or another city) for a night or two; and the villa rustica
column4: the farmhouse estate permanently occupied by the servants who generally had charge of the estate. The Roman Empire contained many kinds of villas
column5: not all of them lavishly appointed with mosaic floors and frescoes.|1

column1: Mariner 3 ( together with Mariner 4 known as Mariner-Mars 1964 ) was one of two identical deep-space probes designed and constructed by the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory ( JPL ). It was the first of the Mars flyby missions which included the first images of the planet. Both Mariner probes carried on board three types of sensors
column2: which provided a global survey of Mars. Mariner 3 flew by the planet Mars at the closest approach of any spacecraft to date on 14 October 1971. It entered orbit around Mars on 11 February 1972 and began gathering data for the first time on the planet's surface.|0

column1: Robert von Ranke Graves ( 24 July 1895 – 7 December 1985 ) was a British poet , historical novelist , biographer , scholar of Greek and Roman history , dramatist , teacher and soldier. Graves was a leading exponent of the "Euhemerism" movement . A poet, novelist and historian, he published his most famous work The White Goddess, in 1948. The novel was written to answer the question of whether or not the gods exist, and the gods that exist are not divine. It is an essay on the relationship between culture, myth and history.|0

Year 1406 ( MCDVI ) was a common year starting on Friday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. The year is divided into 5 distinct seasons:

Year 1556 ( MDLVI ) was a leap year starting on Wednesday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. A Leap Year is a year with 366 days, and begins on 1 of 2 dates:

Leap day = 1 of the month, on a day other than the regular day of the month ( so not the 15th in the month, but on a later day, for example the 16th, 24th, 26th or 31st ). Leap week = on a Thursday of the month ( so that it starts on a Sunday).|0

Year 1181 ( MCLXXXI ) was a common year starting on Thursday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. At that time, the Byzantine Empire reigned in Eastern Europe and Western Asia. A Muslim army, under Khalid ibn Yazid and Caliph Al-Muqtadir, invaded the Byzantine territory (modern day Greece and parts of the Balkan countries). Khalid ibn Yazid entered Constantinople on March 15, 1182

Khalid was killed in battle the following day. The battle was won by the Byzantine army of the Emperor John III Vatatzes. Constantinople capitulated on the 31st to avoid the total destruction of the city.|0
Jacques René Chirac (
column3: ; 29 November 193226 September 2019 ) was a French politician who served as President of France from 1995 to 2002. He is widely regarded as the most influential of the two main political figures who dominated France in the twentieth century: a conservative nationalist of the right who was elected three times as Prime Minister (1974–1976
column6: and then the country's first Socialist president. He is also considered to be the most influential French political figure after World War II. After a long political career he became a member of the École des Hautes Études Commerciales.|0

column1: Palermo ( , ;  , locally also  or ; , from ; older ) is a city in southern Italy, the capital of both the autonomous region of Sicily and the Metropolitan City of Palermo, the city's surrounding metropolitan province. The city is noted for its history, culture, architecture and gastronomy, playing an important role throughout much of its existence; it is over 2,700 years old. Palermo is in the northwest of the island of Sicily, by the Gulf of Palermo in the Tyrrhenian Sea.The city was founded in 734 BC by the Phoenicians as  ("flower").|1

Year 1422 ( MCDXXII ) was a common year starting on Thursday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. Pope Eugene IV elected 

Pope Eugene IV (1547–1555) was born Giuliano della Rovere as the second son of Agapito del Nero, the Duke of Sora. He was a cardinal and the brother of Alessandro della Rovere, the future Duke of Urbino, and a distant cousin of Pope Julius II. He took the name Eugene after the name of Saint Eusebius of Emesa. He was elected pope on January 23, 1545, and he reigned until May 31, 1555.|0

An oak is a tree or shrub in the genus Quercus (; Latin "oak tree") of the beech family, Fagaceae. There are approximately 500 extant species of oaks. The common name "oak" also appears in the names of species in related genera, notably Lithocarpus (stone oaks), as well as in those of unrelated species such as Grevillea robusta (silky oaks) and the Casuarinaceae (she-oaks). The genus Quercus is native to the Northern Hemisphere, and includes deciduous and evergreen species extending from cool temperate to tropical latitudes in the Americas, Asia, Europe, and North Africa.|1

column1: ext3

The standard circulating coinage of the United Kingdom, British Crown Dependencies and British Overseas Territories is denominated in pounds sterling (symbol "£"), and ranges in value from one penny to two pounds. Since decimalisation, on 15 February 1971, the pound has been divided into 100 (new) pence. Before decimalisation, twelve pence made a shilling, and twenty shillings made a pound. British coins are minted by the Royal Mint in Llantrisant, Wales. The Royal Mint also commissions the coins' designs.In addition to the circulating coinage, the UK also mints commemorative decimal coins (crowns) in the denomination of five pounds.|1
A semi-automatic rifle is an autoloading rifle that fires one round each pull of the trigger. For comparison
column2: a bolt-action rifle requires the user to cycle the bolt manually before they can fire a second time
column3: and a fully automatic rifle
column4: provided it has ammunition
column5: will continue to fire until the trigger is released. Most modern automatic rifles are selective fire
column6: meaning the user can fire semi-automatically if desired.HistoryThe first design of a recoil-operated semi-automatic rifle is attributed to Ferdinand Mannlicher
column7: who unveiled the design in 1885 based on work begun in 1883.|1

column1: Optical rotation
column2: also known as polarization rotation or circular birefringence
column3: is the rotation of the orientation of the linear polarization of a beam of light
column4: as it passes through an optically active material (i.e. a material that has an optical axis of rotation). The angle of rotation of the light is proportional to the optical rotatory power of the optically active material and is measured in units of degrees. The first measurements of optical rotatory power were carried out in 1670
column5: by Isaac Newton
column6: who described a method of determining this quantity using his prismatic refractometer.|0

column1:
The foreign relations of Albania are its relations with other governments and peoples . Foreign relations are conducted through the diplomatic missions of the Republic of Albania abroad as well as the embassy and consular representation of Albania to other states within the Republic of Albania

The foreign relations of the country are managed by the Republic of Albania and the foreign ministry. The foreign relations of Albania were guided by the principles of non interference in the affairs of other independent countries, the right to self determination of the peoples of the former Yugoslavia as well as the right of the Albanian minority in Macedonia to be left alone.|0

column1: Mariner 2 (Mariner-Venus 1962)

column1: Aloysius Lilius (c. 1510 – 1576), also variously referred to as Luigi Lilio, Luigi Giglio, was an Italian doctor, astronomer, philosopher and chronologist, and also the "primary author" who provided the proposal that (after modifications) became the basis of the Gregorian Calendar reform of 1582.The crater Lilius on the Moon is named after him, as is the asteroid 2346 Lilio. In computer science, the Lilian date is the number of days since the adoption of the Gregorian calendar on 15 October 1582.Life and workNot much is known about the early life of Lilius/Lilio/Giglio.|1

Vapor pressure ( or vapour pressure in English-speaking counties other than the US ; see spelling differences ) or equilibrium vapor pressure ( ) is the pressure at which saturated vapour exists in a liquid or solid. It is also known as saturation vapour pressure. It is the vapor pressure that exists when all liquid water molecules in a sample have the same temperature
column2: regardless of pressure. Vapor pressure is an important concept when describing the physical properties of a solid or liquid phase. It is used in several fields
column3: including physics
column4: chemistry
column5: and physics.|0
